member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glFinish
member.summary:
Block until all GL execution is complete.
Does not return until the effects of all previously called GL commands are complete. Such effects include all changes to GL state, all changes to connection state, and all changes to the frame buffer contents.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glStencilFuncSeparate(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Set front and/or back function and reference value for stencil testing
member.param:
Specifies whether front and/or back stencil state is updated.
Three symbolic constants are valid: GL_FRONT, GL_BACK, and GL_FRONT_AND_BACK.

Specifies the test function.
Eight symbolic constants are valid: GL_NEVER, GL_LESS, GL_LEQUAL, GL_GREATER, GL_GEQUAL, GL_EQUAL, GL_NOTEQUAL, and GL_ALWAYS. The initial value is GL_ALWAYS
.

Specifies the reference value for the stencil test.
Clamped to the range [0, 2n - 1], where n is the number of bitplanes in the stencil buffer. The initial value is 0.

Specifies a mask that is ANDed with both the reference value and the stored stencil value when the test is done.
The initial value is all 1's.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glStencilOpSeparate(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set front and/or back stencil test actions.
member.param:
Specifies whether front and/or back stencil state is updated.
Three symbolic constants are valid: GL_FRONT, GL_BACK, and GL_FRONT_AND_BACK.

Specifies the action to take when the stencil test fails.
Eight symbolic constants are accepted: GL_KEEP, GL_ZERO, GL_REPLACE, GL_INCR, GL_INCR_WRAP, GL_DECR, GL_DECR_WRAP, and GL_INVERT. The initial value is GL_KEEP.

Specifies the stencil action when the stencil test passes, but the depth test fails. accepts the same symbolic constants as .
The initial value is GL_KEEP.

Specifies the stencil action when both the stencil test and the depth test pass, or when the stencil test passes and either there is no depth buffer or depth testing is not enabled. dppassâ€‹ accepts the same symbolic constants as â€‹.
The initial value is GL_KEEP.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glStencilMaskSeparate(System.Int32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Control the front and/or back writing of individual bits in the stencil planes.
member.param:
Specifies whether the front and/or back stencil writemask is updated.
Three symbolic constants are valid: GL_FRONT, GL_BACK, and GL_FRONT_AND_BACK.
Specifies a bit mask to enable and disable writing of individual bits in the stencil planes. Initially, the mask is all 1's.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glVertexAttribPointer(System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Void*)
member.summary: Define an array of generic vertex attribute data
member.param: Specifies the index of the generic vertex attribute to be modified.

Specifies the number of components per generic vertex attribute.
Must be 1, 2, 3, 4, or .
Specifies the data type of each component in the array.
Specifies whether fixed-point data values should be normalized (true) or converted directly as fixed-point values (false) when they are accessed.

Specifies the byte offset between consecutive generic vertex attributes.
If stride is 0, the generic vertex attributes are understood to be tightly packed in the array.
Specifies a offset of the first component of the first generic vertex attribute in the array in the data store of the buffer currently bound to the GL_ARRAY_BUFFER target.

member.summary: Specifies the value of a generic packed vertex attribute.
member.param: Specifies the index of the generic vertex attribute to be modified.
Specifies the type of packing used on the data.

true values are to be converted to floating point values by normalizing.
Otherwise, they are converted directly to floating-point values. If type indicates a floating-point format, then normalized value must be false.
A pointer to the new packed values to be used for the specified vertex attribute.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glVertexAttribIPointer(System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Void*)
member.summary: Define an array of generic vertex attribute data.
member.param: Specifies the index of the generic vertex attribute to be modified.

Specifies the number of components per generic vertex attribute.
Must be 1, 2, 3, 4 or GL_BGRA.
Specifies the data type of each component in the array.

Specifies the byte offset between consecutive generic vertex attributes.
If stride is 0, the generic vertex attributes are understood to be tightly packed in the array.The initial value is 0.

The initial value is 0.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glTexImage2DMultisample(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Establish the data storage, format, dimensions, and number of samples of a multisample texture's image
member.param:
Specifies the target of the operation.
Must be GL_TEXTURE_2D_MULTISAMPLE or GL_PROXY_TEXTURE_2D_MULTISAMPLE.
The number of samples in the multisample texture's image.

The internal format to be used to store the multisample texture's image.
Must specify a color-renderable, depth-renderable, or stencil-renderable format.
The width of the multisample texture's image, in texels.
The height of the multisample texture's image, in texels.

Specifies whether the image will use identical sample locations and the same number of samples for all texels in the image, and the sample locations will not depend on the internal format or size of the image.

member.name: M:Emission.Graphics.GL.GL.glTexImage3DMultisample(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)

The number of samples in the multisample texture's image.

The internal format to be used to store the multisample texture's image.
Must specify a color-renderable, depth-renderable, or stencil-renderable format.
The width of the multisample texture's image, in texels.
The height of the multisample texture's image, in texels.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.Unknown
member.summary: An unknown or undefined error.

member.summary: No error has occurred.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.NotInitialized
member.summary: This occurs if a GLFW function was called that must not be called unless the library is initialized.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.NoCurrentContext
member.summary: This occurs if a GLFW function was called that needs and operates on the current OpenGL or OpenGL ES context but no context is current on the calling thread.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.InvalidEnum
member.summary: One of the arguments to the function was an invalid enum value.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.InvalidValue
member.summary: One of the arguments to the function was an invalid value, for example requesting a non-existent OpenGL or OpenGL ES version like 2.7.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.OutOfMemory
member.summary: A memory allocation failed.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.ApiUnavailable
member.summary: GLFW could not find support for the requested API on the system.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.VersionUnavailable
member.summary: The requested OpenGL or OpenGL ES version (including any requested context or framebuffer hints) is not available on this machine.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.PlatformError
member.summary: A platform-specific error occurred that does not match any of the more specific categories.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.FormatUnavailable
member.summary: If emitted during window creation, the requested pixel format is not supported, else if emitted when querying the clipboard, the contents of the clipboard could not be converted to the requested format.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCode.NoWindowContext
member.summary: A window that does not have an OpenGL or OpenGL ES context was passed to a function that requires it to have one.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Vulkan.GetInstanceProcAddress(System.IntPtr,System.String)
member.summary:
This function returns the address of the specified Vulkan core or extension function for the specified instance. If instance is set to it can return any function exported from the Vulkan loader.
If Vulkan is not available on the machine, this function returns and generates an error. Use to check whether Vulkan is available.
member.param: The vulkan instance.
Name of the function.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Vulkan.GetRequiredInstanceExtensions
member.summary:
This function returns an array of names of Vulkan instance extensions required by GLFW for creating Vulkan surfaces for GLFW windows. If successful, the list will always contains VK_KHR_surface, so if you don't require any additional extensions you can pass this list directly to the VkInstanceCreateInfo struct.
If Vulkan is not available on the machine, this function returns generates an error, use to first check if supported.
If Vulkan is available but no set of extensions allowing window surface creation was found, this function returns an empty array. You may still use Vulkan for off-screen rendering and compute work.
member.returns: An array of extension names.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetMonitorContentScale(System.IntPtr,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary:
Retrieves the content scale for the specified monitor. The content scale is the ratio between the current DPI and the platform's default DPI.
This is especially important for text and any UI elements. If the pixel dimensions of your UI scaled by this look appropriate on your machine then it should appear at a reasonable size on other machines regardless of their DPI and scaling settings. This relies on the system DPI and scaling settings being somewhat correct.
member.param: The monitor to query.
The scale on the x-axis.
The scale on the y-axis.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetWindowContentScale(System.IntPtr,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary:
Retrieves the content scale for the specified window. The content scale is the ratio between the current DPI and the platform's default DPI. This is especially important for text and any UI elements. If the pixel dimensions of your UI scaled by this look appropriate on your machine then it should appear at a reasonable size on other machines regardless of their DPI and scaling settings. This relies on the system DPI and scaling settings being somewhat correct.
On systems where each monitors can have its own content scale, the window content scale will depend on which monitor the system considers the window to be on.
member.param: The window to query.
The content scale on the x-axis.
The content scale on the y-axis.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.InitHint(Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
This function sets hints for the next initialization of GLFW.
The values you set hints to are never reset by GLFW, but they only take effect during initialization. Once GLFW has been initialized, any values you set will be ignored until the library is terminated and initialized again.>.
member.param: The hint, valid values are , , and .

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.Init
member.summary:
This function initializes the GLFW library. Before most GLFW functions can be used, GLFW must be initialized, and before an application terminates GLFW should be terminated in order to free any resources allocated during or after initialization.
If this function fails, it calls before returning. If it succeeds, you should call before the application exits
Additional calls to this function after successful initialization but before termination will return true immediately.
member.returns: true if successful, or false if an error occurred.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.Terminate
member.summary: This function destroys all remaining windows and cursors, restores any modified gamma ramps and frees any other allocated resources. Once this function is called, you must again call successfully before you will be able to use most GLFW functions. If GLFW has been successfully initialized, this function should be called before the application exits. If initialization fails, there is no need to call this function, as it is called by before it returns failure.
member.note: The contexts of any remaining windows must not be current on any other thread when this function is called.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetErrorCallback(Emission.Window.GLFW.ErrorCallback)

member.returns: The previously set callback function, or null if no callback was already set.

This function destroys the specified window and its context. On calling this function, no further callbacks will be called for that window.

member.summary:
This function retrieves the size, in screen coordinates, of each edge of the frame of the specified window.
This size includes the title bar, if the window has one. The size of the frame may vary depending on the window-related hints used to create it.
Because this function retrieves the size of each window frame edge and not the offset along a particular coordinate axis, the retrieved values will always be zero or positive.
member.param: A window instance.
The size, in screen coordinates, of the left edge of the window frame
The size, in screen coordinates, of the top edge of the window frame

member.summary:
This function maximizes the specified window if it was previously not maximized. If the window is already maximized, this function does nothing.
If the specified window is a full screen window, this function does nothing.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.IconifyWindow(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
This function iconifies (minimizes) the specified window if it was previously restored.
If the window is already iconified, this function does nothing.
member.param: A window instance.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.RestoreWindow(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
This function restores the specified window if it was previously iconified (minimized) or maximized.
If the window is already restored, this function does nothing.
If the specified window is a full screen window, the resolution chosen for the window is restored on the selected monitor.
member.param: A window instance.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.MakeContextCurrent(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
This function makes the OpenGL or OpenGL ES context of the specified window current on the calling thread.
A context can only be made current on a single thread at a time and each thread can have only a single current context at a time.
By default, making a context non-current implicitly forces a pipeline flush.
member.param: A window instance.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SwapBuffers(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
This function swaps the front and back buffers of the specified window when rendering with OpenGL or OpenGL ES.
If the swap interval is greater than zero, the GPU driver waits the specified number of screen updates before swapping the buffers.
This function does not apply to Vulkan.
member.param: A window instance.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SwapInterval(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the swap interval for the current OpenGL or OpenGL ES context, i.e. the number of screen updates to wait from the time was called before swapping the buffers and returning.
This is sometimes called vertical synchronization, vertical retrace synchronization or just vsync.
A context must be current on the calling thread. Calling this function without a current context will cause an exception.
This function does not apply to Vulkan. If you are rendering with Vulkan, see the present mode of your swapchain instead.
member.param: The minimum number of screen updates to wait for until the buffers are swapped by .

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetExtensionSupported(System.Byte[])
member.summary:
Gets whether the specified API extension is supported by the current OpenGL or OpenGL ES context.
It searches both for client API extension and context creation API extensions.
member.param: The extension name as an array of ASCII encoded bytes.
member.returns: true if the extension is supported; otherwise false.

member.summary:
Sets the icon of the specified window. If passed an array of candidate images, those of or closest to the sizes desired by the system are selected. If no images are specified, the window reverts to its default icon.
The desired image sizes varies depending on platform and system settings. The selected images will be rescaled as needed. Good sizes include 16x16, 32x32 and 48x48.
member.param: A window instance.
The number of images in .
An array of icon images.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.WaitEvents
member.summary:
This function puts the calling thread to sleep until at least one event is available in the event queue. Once one or more events are available, it behaves exactly like glfwPollEvents, i.e. the events in the queue are processed and the function then returns immediately. Processing events will cause the window and input callbacks associated with those events to be called.
Since not all events are associated with callbacks, this function may return without a callback having been called even if you are monitoring all callbacks.
On some platforms, a window move, resize or menu operation will cause event processing to block. This is due to how event processing is designed on those platforms. You can use the window refresh callback to redraw the contents of your window when necessary during such operations.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.PollEvents
member.summary:
This function processes only those events that are already in the event queue and then returns immediately. Processing events will cause the window and input callbacks associated with those events to be called.
On some platforms, a window move, resize or menu operation will cause event processing to block. This is due to how event processing is designed on those platforms. You can use the window refresh callback to redraw the contents of your window when necessary during such operations.
On some platforms, certain events are sent directly to the application without going through the event queue, causing callbacks to be called outside of a call to one of the event processing functions.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.PostEmptyEvent
member.summary: This function posts an empty event from the current thread to the event queue, causing or to return.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.WaitEventsTimeout(System.Double)
member.summary:
This function puts the calling thread to sleep until at least one event is available in the event queue, or until the specified timeout is reached. If one or more events are available, it behaves exactly like , i.e. the events in the queue are processed and the function then returns immediately. Processing events will cause the window and input callbacks associated with those events to be called.
The timeout value must be a positive finite number.
Since not all events are associated with callbacks, this function may return without a callback having been called even if you are monitoring all callbacks.
On some platforms, a window move, resize or menu operation will cause event processing to block. This is due to how event processing is designed on those platforms. You can use the window refresh callback to redraw the contents of your window when necessary during such operations.
member.param: The maximum amount of time, in seconds, to wait.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetCloseCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowCallback)
member.summary: Sets the close callback of the specified window, which is called when the user attempts to close the window, for example by clicking the close widget in the title bar.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetWindowMonitor(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Gets the handle of the monitor that the specified window is in full screen on.
member.param: A window instance.
member.returns: The monitor, or if the window is in windowed mode or an error occurred.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetWindowMonitor(System.IntPtr,Emission.Monitor,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the monitor that the window uses for full screen mode or, if the monitor is , makes it windowed mode.
When setting a monitor, this function updates the width, height and refresh rate of the desired video mode and switches to the video mode closest to it. The window position is ignored when setting a monitor.
When the monitor is , the position, width and height are used to place the window client area. The refresh rate is ignored when no monitor is specified.
If you only wish to update the resolution of a full screen window or the size of a windowed mode window, use .
When a window transitions from full screen to windowed mode, this function restores any previous window settings such as whether it is decorated, floating, resizable, has size or aspect ratio limits, etc..
member.param: A window instance.
The desired monitor, or to set windowed mode.
The desired x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the client area.
The desired y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the client area.
The desired width, in screen coordinates, of the client area or video mode.
The desired height, in screen coordinates, of the client area or video mode.
The desired refresh rate, in Hz, of the video mode, or .

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetGammaRamp(Emission.Monitor,Emission.Window.GLFW.GammaRamp)
member.summary:
Sets the current gamma ramp for the specified monitor.
The original gamma ramp for that monitor is saved by GLFW the first time this function is called and is restored by .
WARNING: Gamma ramps with sizes other than 256 are not supported on some platforms (Windows).
member.param: The monitor whose gamma ramp to set.
The gamma ramp to use.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetGamma(Emission.Monitor,System.Single)
member.summary:
This function generates a 256-element gamma ramp from the specified exponent and then calls with it.
The value must be a finite number greater than zero.
member.param: The monitor whose gamma ramp to set.
The desired exponent.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetDropCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.FileDropCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the file drop callback of the specified window, which is called when one or more dragged files are dropped on the window.
Because the path array and its strings may have been generated specifically for that event, they are not guaranteed to be valid after the callback has returned. If you wish to use them after the callback returns, you need to make a deep copy.
member.param: The window whose callback to set.
The new file drop callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.CreateCursor(Emission.IO.Icon,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Creates a new custom cursor image that can be set for a window with glfwSetCursor.
The cursor can be destroyed with . Any remaining cursors are destroyed by .
The pixels are 32-bit, little-endian, non-premultiplied RGBA, i.e. eight bits per channel. They are arranged canonically as packed sequential rows, starting from the top-left corner.
The cursor hotspot is specified in pixels, relative to the upper-left corner of the cursor image. Like all other coordinate systems in GLFW, the X-axis points to the right and the Y-axis points down.
member.param: The image.
The x hotspot.
The y hotspot.
member.returns: The created cursor.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.DestroyCursor(Emission.Window.Cursor)
member.summary: This function destroys a cursor previously created with . Any remaining cursors will be destroyed by .
member.param: The cursor object to destroy.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetCursor(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.Cursor)
member.summary:
Sets the cursor image to be used when the cursor is over the client area of the specified window.
The set cursor will only be visible when the cursor mode of the window is .
member.param: A window instance.
The cursor to set, or to switch back to the default arrow cursor.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.CreateStandardCursor(Emission.Window.GLFW.CursorType)
member.summary: Returns a cursor with a standard shape, that can be set for a window with .
member.param: The type of cursor to create.
member.returns: A new cursor ready to use or if an error occurred.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetCursorPosition(System.IntPtr,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary:
Gets the position of the cursor, in screen coordinates, relative to the upper-left corner of the client area of the specified window
If the cursor is disabled then the cursor position is unbounded and limited only by the minimum and maximum values of a double.
The coordinate can be converted to their integer equivalents with the floor function. Casting directly to an integer type works for positive coordinates, but fails for negative ones.
member.param: A window instance.
The cursor x-coordinate, relative to the left edge of the client area.
The cursor y-coordinate, relative to the left edge of the client area.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetCursorPosition(System.IntPtr,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Sets the position, in screen coordinates, of the cursor relative to the upper-left corner of the client area of the specified window. The window must have input focus. If the window does not have input focus when this function is called, it fails silently.
If the cursor mode is disabled then the cursor position is unconstrained and limited only by the minimum and maximum values of a .
member.param: A window instance.
The desired x-coordinate, relative to the left edge of the client area.
The desired y-coordinate, relative to the left edge of the client area.

member.summary:
Sets the cursor position callback of the specified window, which is called when the cursor is moved.
The callback is provided with the position, in screen coordinates, relative to the upper-left corner of the client area of the window.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, ornull if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.summary: Sets the cursor boundary crossing callback of the specified window, which is called when the cursor enters or leaves the client area of the window.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetMouseButtonCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.MouseButtonCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the mouse button callback of the specified window, which is called when a mouse button is pressed or released.
When a window loses input focus, it will generate synthetic mouse button release events for all pressed mouse buttons. You can tell these events from user-generated events by the fact that the synthetic ones are generated after the focus loss event has been processed, i.e. after the window focus callback has been called.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetScrollCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.MouseCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the scroll callback of the specified window, which is called when a scrolling device is used, such as a mouse wheel or scrolling area of a touchpad.
The scroll callback receives all scrolling input, like that from a mouse wheel or a touchpad scrolling area.
member.param: A window instance.
The new scroll callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetMouseButton(System.IntPtr,Emission.MouseButton)
member.summary:
Gets the last state reported for the specified mouse button to the specified window.
If the input mode is enabled, this function returns the first time you call it for a mouse button that was pressed, even if that mouse button has already been released.
member.param: A window instance.
The desired mouse button.
member.returns: The input state of the .

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetWindowSizeLimits(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the size limits of the client area of the specified window. If the window is full screen, the size limits only take effect once it is made windowed. If the window is not resizable, this function does nothing.
The size limits are applied immediately to a windowed mode window and may cause it to be resized.
The maximum dimensions must be greater than or equal to the minimum dimensions and all must be greater than or equal to zero.
member.param: A window instance.
The minimum width of the client area.
The minimum height of the client area.
The maximum width of the client area.
The maximum height of the client area.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetWindowAspectRatio(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the required aspect ratio of the client area of the specified window. If the window is full screen, the aspect ratio only takes effect once it is made windowed. If the window is not resizable, this function does nothing.
The aspect ratio is specified as a numerator and a denominator and both values must be greater than zero. For example, the common 16:9 aspect ratio is specified as 16 and 9, respectively.
If the numerator and denominator is set to then the aspect ratio limit is disabled.
The aspect ratio is applied immediately to a windowed mode window and may cause it to be resized.
member.param: A window instance.
The numerator of the desired aspect ratio.
The denominator of the desired aspect ratio.

member.summary: Gets the size, in millimeters, of the display area of the specified monitor.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetMonitorPosition(Emission.Monitor,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetCharCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.CharCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the character callback of the specified window, which is called when a Unicode character is input.
The character callback is intended for Unicode text input. As it deals with characters, it is keyboard layout dependent, whereas the key callback is not. Characters do not map 1:1 to physical keys, as a key may produce zero, one or more characters. If you want to know whether a specific physical key was pressed or released, see the key callback instead.
The character callback behaves as system text input normally does and will not be called if modifier keys are held down that would prevent normal text input on that platform, for example a Super (Command) key on OS X or Alt key on Windows. There is a character with modifiers callback that receives these events.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetCharModsCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.CharModsCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the character with modifiers callback of the specified window, which is called when a Unicode character is input regardless of what modifier keys are used.
The character with modifiers callback is intended for implementing custom Unicode character input. For regular Unicode text input, see the character callback. Like the character callback, the character with modifiers callback deals with characters and is keyboard layout dependent. Characters do not map 1:1 to physical keys, as a key may produce zero, one or more characters. If you want to know whether a specific physical key was pressed or released, see the key callback instead.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or an error occurred.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.GetKey(System.IntPtr,Emission.Keys)
member.summary:
Gets the last state reported for the specified key to the specified window.
The higher-level action is only reported to the key callback.
If the sticky keys input mode is enabled, this function returns the first time you call it for a key that was pressed, even if that key has already been released.
The key functions deal with physical keys, with key tokens named after their use on the standard US keyboard layout. If you want to input text, use the Unicode character callback instead.
member.param: A window instance.
The key to query.
member.returns: Either or .

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetFramebufferSizeCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.SizeCallback)
member.summary: Sets the framebuffer resize callback of the specified window, which is called when the framebuffer of the specified window is resized.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetWindowRefreshCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the refresh callback of the specified window, which is called when the client area of the window needs to be redrawn, for example if the window has been exposed after having been covered by another window.
On compositing window systems such as Aero, Compiz or Aqua, where the window contents are saved off-screen, this callback may be called only very infrequently or never at all.
member.param: A window instance.
The new callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: M:Emission.Window.GLFW.Glfw.SetKeyCallback(System.IntPtr,Emission.Window.GLFW.KeyCallback)
member.summary:
Sets the key callback of the specified window, which is called when a key is pressed, repeated or released.
The key functions deal with physical keys, with layout independent key tokens named after their values in the standard US keyboard layout. If you want to input text, use the character callback instead.
When a window loses input focus, it will generate synthetic key release events for all pressed keys. You can tell these events from user-generated events by the fact that the synthetic ones are generated after the focus loss event has been processed, i.e. after the window focus callback has been called.
The scancode of a key is specific to that platform or sometimes even to that machine. Scancodes are intended to allow users to bind keys that don't have a GLFW key token. Such keys have key set to , their state is not saved and so it cannot be queried with .
Sometimes GLFW needs to generate synthetic key events, in which case the scancode may be zero.
member.param: The new key callback, or null to remove the currently set callback.
The key callback.
member.returns: The previously set callback, or null if no callback was set or the library had not been initialized.

member.name: T:Emission.Window.GLFW.ReleaseBehavior
member.summary: Describes the release behavior to be used by the context.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ReleaseBehavior.Any
member.summary: The default behavior of the context creation API will be used.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ReleaseBehavior.Flush
member.summary: The pipeline will be flushed whenever the context is released from being the current one.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.ReleaseBehavior.None
member.summary: The pipeline will not be flushed on release.

member.name: T:Emission.Window.GLFW.Robustness
member.summary: Describes the robustness strategy to be used by the context.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.Robustness.None
member.summary: Disabled/no strategy (default)

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.Robustness.NoResetNotification
member.summary: No notification.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.Robustness.LoseContextOnReset
member.summary: The context is lost on reset, use glGetGraphicsResetStatus for more information.

member.name: T:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode
member.summary: Structure that describes a single video mode.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode.Width
member.summary: The width, in screen coordinates, of the video mode.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode.Height
member.summary: The height, in screen coordinates, of the video mode.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode.RedBits
member.summary: The bit depth of the red channel of the video mode.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode.GreenBits
member.summary: The bit depth of the green channel of the video mode.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode.BlueBits

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.VideoMode.RefreshRate
member.summary: The refresh rate, in Hz, of the video mode.

member.name: T:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute
member.summary: Strongly-typed values used for getting/setting window hints.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.Focused
member.summary:
Indicates whether the windowed mode window will be given input focus when created.
This hint is ignored for full screen and initially hidden windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.AutoIconify
member.summary:
Indicates whether the full screen window will automatically iconify and restore the previous video mode on input focus loss.
This hint is ignored for windowed mode windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.Maximized
member.summary:
Indicates whether the windowed mode window will be maximized when created.
This hint is ignored for full screen windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.Visible
member.summary:
Indicates whether the windowed mode window will be initially visible.
This hint is ignored for full screen windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.Resizable
member.summary:
Indicates whether the windowed mode window will be resizable by the user.
The window will still be resizable using the function.
This hint is ignored for full screen windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.Decorated
member.summary:
Indicates whether the windowed mode window will have window decorations such as a border, a close widget, etc.
An undecorated window may still allow the user to generate close events on some platforms.
This hint is ignored for full screen windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.Floating
member.summary:
Indicates whether the windowed mode window will be floating above other regular windows, also called topmost or always-on-top.
This is intended primarily for debugging purposes and cannot be used to implement proper full screen windows.
This hint is ignored for full screen windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowAttribute.MouseHover
member.summary: Indicates whether the cursor is currently directly over the content area of the window, with no other windows between.

member.name: T:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint
member.summary: Strongly-typed values for setting window hints.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Focused
member.summary:
Specifies whether the windowed mode window will be given input focus when created. This hint is ignored for full screen and initially hidden windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Resizable
member.summary:
Specifies whether the windowed mode window will be resizable by the user. The window will still be resizable programmatically. This hint is ignored for full screen windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Visible
member.summary:
Specifies whether the windowed mode window will be initially visible.This hint is ignored for full screen windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Decorated
member.summary:
Specifies whether the windowed mode window will have window decorations such as a border, a close widget, etc.An undecorated window may still allow the user to generate close events on some platforms.This hint is ignored for full screen windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AutoIconify
member.summary:
Specifies whether the full screen window will automatically iconify and restore the previous video mode on input focus loss. This hint is ignored for windowed mode windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Floating
member.summary:
Specifies whether the windowed mode window will be floating above other regular windows, also called topmost or always-on-top.This is intended primarily for debugging purposes and cannot be used to implement proper full screen windows. This hint is ignored for full screen windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Maximized
member.summary:
Specifies whether the windowed mode window will be maximized when created. This hint is ignored for full screen windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.RedBits
member.summary:
Specifies the desired bit depth of the red component for default framebuffer. means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 8
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.GreenBits
member.summary:
Specifies the desired bit depth of the green component for default framebuffer. means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 8
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.BlueBits
member.summary:
Specifies the desired bit depth of the blue component for default framebuffer. means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 8
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AlphaBits
member.summary:
Specifies the desired bit depth of the alpha component for default framebuffer. means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 8
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.DepthBits
member.summary:
Specifies the desired bit depth of for default framebuffer. "/> means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 24
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.StencilBits
member.summary:
Specifies the desired stencil bits for default framebuffer. means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AccumRedBits
member.summary:
Specify the desired bit depths of the red component of the accumulation buffer. means the application has no preference.
Accumulation buffers are a legacy OpenGL feature and should not be used in new code.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AccumGreenBits
member.summary:
Specify the desired bit depths of the green component of the accumulation buffer. means the application has no preference.
Accumulation buffers are a legacy OpenGL feature and should not be used in new code.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AccumBlueBits
member.summary:
Specify the desired bit depths of the blue component of the accumulation buffer. means the application has no preference.
Accumulation buffers are a legacy OpenGL feature and should not be used in new code.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AccumAlphaBits
member.summary:
Specify the desired bit depths of the alpha component of the accumulation buffer.
means the application has no preference.
Accumulation buffers are a legacy OpenGL feature and should not be used in new code.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.AuxBuffers
member.summary:
Specifies the desired number of auxiliary buffers. means the application has no preference.
Auxiliary buffers are a legacy OpenGL feature and should not be used in new code.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Stereo
member.summary:
Specifies whether to use stereoscopic rendering.
This is a hard constraint.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Samples
member.summary:
Specifies the desired number of samples to use for multisampling.Zero disables multisampling.
means the application has no preference.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.SrgbCapable
member.summary:
Specifies whether the framebuffer should be sRGB capable. If supported, a created OpenGL context will support the GL_FRAMEBUFFER_SRGB enable, also called GL_FRAMEBUFFER_SRGB_EXT) for controlling sRGB rendering and a created OpenGL ES context will always have sRGB rendering enabled.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.Doublebuffer
member.summary:
Specifies whether the framebuffer should be double buffered.You nearly always want to use double buffering.
This is a hard constraint.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.RefreshRate
member.summary:
Specifies the desired refresh rate for full screen windows.
If set to , the highest available refresh rate will be used.
This hint is ignored for windowed mode windows.
Default Value:
Possible Values: 0 to or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ClientApi
member.summary:
Specifies which client API to create the context for.
This is a hard constraint.
Default Value:
Possible Values: Any of values.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ContextCreationApi
member.summary:
Specifies which context creation API to use to create the context.
If no client API is requested, this hint is ignored.
This is a hard constraint.
Default Value:
Possible Values: Any of values.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ContextVersionMajor
member.summary:
Specify the client API major version that the created context must be compatible with.
The exact behavior of this hint depends on the requested client API, see remarks for details.
Default Value: 1
Possible Values: Any valid major version of the chosen client API

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ContextVersionMinor
member.summary:
Specify the client API minor version that the created context must be compatible with.
The exact behavior of this hint depends on the requested client API, see remarks for details.
Default Value: 0
Possible Values: Any valid minor version of the chosen client API

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ContextRobustness
member.summary:
Specifies the robustness strategy to be used by the context.
Default Value:
Possible Values: Any of values

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.OpenglForwardCompatible
member.summary:
Specifies whether the OpenGL context should be forward-compatible, i.e. one where all functionality deprecated in the requested version of OpenGL is removed.
This must only be used if the requested OpenGL version is 3.0 or above.
If OpenGL ES is requested, this hint is ignored
Forward-compatibility is described in detail in the OpenGL Reference Manual.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.OpenglDebugContext
member.summary:
Specifies whether to create a debug OpenGL context, which may have additional error and performance issue reporting functionality.
If OpenGL ES is requested, this hint is ignored.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.OpenglProfile
member.summary:
Specifies which OpenGL profile to create the context for.
If requesting an OpenGL version below 3.2, must be used.
If OpenGL ES is requested, this hint is ignored.
OpenGL profiles are described in detail in the OpenGL Reference Manual.
Default Value:
Possible Values: Any of values

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ContextReleaseBehavior
member.summary:
Specifies the release behavior to be used by the context.
Default Value:
Possible Values: Any of values

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ContextNoError
member.summary:
Specifies whether errors should be generated by the context. If enabled, situations that would have generated errors instead cause undefined behavior.
Default Value:
Possible Values: or .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.JoystickHatButtons
member.summary: Specifies whether to also expose joystick hats as buttons, for compatibility with earlier versions of GLFW (less than 3.3) that did not have .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.CocoaChDirResources
member.summary:
Specifies whether to set the current directory to the application to the Contents/Resources subdirectory of the application's bundle, if present.
macOS ONLY!

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.CocoaMenuBar
member.summary:
Specifies whether to create a basic menu bar, either from a nib or manually, when the first window is created, which is when AppKit is initialized.
macOS ONLY!

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.CenterCursor
member.summary:
Specifies whether the cursor should be centered over newly created full screen windows.
Possible values are true and false.
This hint is ignored for windowed mode windows.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.TransparentFramebuffer
member.summary:
Specifies whether the window framebuffer will be transparent.
If enabled and supported by the system, the window framebuffer alpha channel will be used to combine the framebuffer with the background. This does not affect window decorations.
Possible values are true and false.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.FocusOnShow
member.summary:
Specifies whether the window will be given input focus when is called.
Possible values are true and false.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.ScaleToMonitor
member.summary:
Specifies whether the window content area should be resized based on the monitor content scale of any monitor it is placed on. This includes the initial placement when the window is created.
Possible values are true and false.
This hint only has an effect on platforms where screen coordinates and pixels always map 1:1 such as Windows and X11. On platforms like macOS the resolution of the framebuffer is changed independently of the window size.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.CocoaRetinaFrameBuffer
member.summary:
Specifies whether to use full resolution framebuffers on Retina displays.
Possible values are true and false.
This is ignored on other platforms.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.CocoaFrameName
member.summary:
Specifies the UTF-8 encoded name to use for auto-saving the window frame, or if empty disables frame auto-saving for the window.
macOs only, this is ignored on other platforms.
This is set with .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.CocoaGraphicsSwitching
member.summary:
Specifies whether to in Automatic Graphics Switching, i.e. to allow the system to choose the integrated GPU for the OpenGL context and move it between GPUs if necessary or whether to force it to always run on the discrete GPU.
This only affects systems with both integrated and discrete GPUs, ignored on other platforms.
Possible values are true and false.

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.X11ClassName
member.summary:
Specifies the desired ASCII encoded class parts of the ICCCM WM_CLASS window property.
Set with .

member.name: F:Emission.Window.GLFW.WindowHint.X11InstanceName
member.summary:
Specifies the desired ASCII encoded instance parts of the ICCCM WM_CLASS window property.
Set with .

member.name: T:Emission.Window.Cursor
member.summary: Wrapper around a handle for a window cursor object.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Handle
member.summary: Pointer to Glfw Window object. Represent window. Public get and can be only set class constructor.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Parameters
member.summary: Structure that contains all information to generate window. Information cannot be change, so it can be used to get starting value for the width or the title for example.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.WindowAspect
member.summary: Return, as float value, the relationship between the width and the height of the screen. Calculate with . Cannot be set, readonly.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.WindowPosition
member.summary: Use a Vector2 with int values to get window's position in computer screen space. Can be set or get. Call to define position.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.WindowSize
member.summary: Use a Vector2 with int values to get Window current size in pixels. Can be set or get. Call to define size.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Maximized
member.summary: Return a boolean when the window is maximized on the current monitor. Can be set or get. When is set, it maximized the window when value is true and restore his size when it's false.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Minimized
member.summary: Return a boolean when the window is minimized on the current monitor. Can be set or get. When is set, it minimized the window when value is true and restore his size when it's false.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Title
member.summary: Return or set window's title. Use private variable to save current title. When the title need to change, it define the private variable and then change title using .

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Visible
member.summary: Return if the window is visible or not. Use attribute to get the value. If visibility need the be set, if it's true, the window will be show, otherwise the window will be hide.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Focus
member.summary: Warper for with while returning value and when value is set.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.ShouldClose
member.summary: Warper for while returning value and when value is set.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Opacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the opacity of the window in the range of 0.0f and 1.0f.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.ClearColor
member.summary: Gets the clear color of the window.

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Viewport
member.summary: Viewport of the window. Countains WindowSize and Window Position

member.name: P:Emission.Window.Window.Behaviour
member.summary: Engine Behaviour of the Window.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could be null sometimes, so checking for null is required before its usage.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element can never be null.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ItemNotNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be applied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can never be null.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ItemCanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be applied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can be null.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method builds string by the format pattern and (optional) arguments. The parameter, which contains the format string, should be given in constructor. The format string should be in -like form.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Specifies which parameter of an annotated method should be treated as the format string

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ValueProviderAttribute
member.summary: Use this annotation to specify a type that contains static or const fields with values for the annotated property/field/parameter. The specified type will be used to improve completion suggestions.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InvokerParameterNameAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the function argument should be a string literal and match one of the parameters of the caller function. For example, ReSharper annotates the parameter of .

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed.
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If the method has a single input parameter, its name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for the method output means that the method doesn't return normally (throws or terminates the process).
Value canbenull is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon. There is no notion of order rows, all rows are checked for applicability and applied per each program state tracked by the analysis engine.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("null <= param:null")] // reverse condition syntax public string GetName(string surname)
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("=> true, result: notnull; => false, result: null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.LocalizationRequiredAttribute
member.summary: Indicates whether the marked element should be localized.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CannotApplyEqualityOperatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked type (or its derivatives) cannot be compared using '==' or '!=' operators and Equals() should be used instead. However, using '==' or '!=' for comparison with null is always permitted.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.BaseTypeRequiredAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a target attribute, specifies a requirement for any type marked with the target attribute to implement or inherit specific type or types.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.UsedImplicitlyAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked symbol is used implicitly (e.g. via reflection, in external library), so this symbol will not be reported as unused (as well as by other usage inspections).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MeansImplicitUseAttribute
member.summary: Can be applied to attributes, type parameters, and parameters of a type assignable from . When applied to an attribute, the decorated attribute behaves the same as . When applied to a type parameter or to a parameter of type , indicates that the corresponding type is used implicitly.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags
member.summary: Specify the details of implicitly used symbol when it is marked with or .

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.Access
member.summary: Only entity marked with attribute considered used.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.Assign
member.summary: Indicates implicit assignment to a member.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.InstantiatedWithFixedConstructorSignature
member.summary: Indicates implicit instantiation of a type with fixed constructor signature. That means any unused constructor parameters won't be reported as such.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.InstantiatedNoFixedConstructorSignature
member.summary: Indicates implicit instantiation of a type.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags
member.summary: Specify what is considered to be used implicitly when marked with or .

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.Members
member.summary: Members of entity marked with attribute are considered used.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.WithMembers
member.summary: Entity marked with attribute and all its members considered used.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PublicAPIAttribute
member.summary: This attribute is intended to mark publicly available API which should not be removed and so is treated as used.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InstantHandleAttribute
member.summary: Tells code analysis engine if the parameter is completely handled when the invoked method is on stack. If the parameter is a delegate, indicates that delegate is executed while the method is executed. If the parameter is an enumerable, indicates that it is enumerated while the method is executed.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PureAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method does not make any observable state changes. The same as System.Diagnostics.Contracts.PureAttribute.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MustUseReturnValueAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the return value of the method invocation must be used.
member.remarks:
Methods decorated with this attribute (in contrast to pure methods) might change state, but make no sense without using their return value.
Similarly to , this attribute will help detecting usages of the method when the return value in not used. Additionally, you can optionally specify a custom message, which will be used when showing warnings, e.g. [MustUseReturnValue("Use the return value to...")].

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ProvidesContextAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the type member or parameter of some type, that should be used instead of all other ways to get the value of that type. This annotation is useful when you have some "context" value evaluated and stored somewhere, meaning that all other ways to get this value must be consolidated with existing one.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PathReferenceAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a parameter is a path to a file or a folder within a web project. Path can be relative or absolute, starting from web root (~).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.SourceTemplateAttribute
member.summary: An extension method marked with this attribute is processed by code completion as a 'Source Template'. When the extension method is completed over some expression, its source code is automatically expanded like a template at call site.
member.remarks: Template method body can contain valid source code and/or special comments starting with '$'. Text inside these comments is added as source code when the template is applied. Template parameters can be used either as additional method parameters or as identifiers wrapped in two '$' signs. Use the attribute to specify macros for parameters.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro for a parameter of a source template.
member.remarks: You can apply the attribute on the whole method or on any of its additional parameters. The macro expression is defined in the property. When applied on a method, the target template parameter is defined in the property. To apply the macro silently for the parameter, set the property value = -1.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Expression
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro that will be executed for a source template parameter when the template is expanded.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Editable
member.summary: Allows specifying which occurrence of the target parameter becomes editable when the template is deployed.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Target
member.summary: Identifies the target parameter of a source template if the is applied on a template method.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessAttribute
member.summary: Indicates how method, constructor invocation, or property access over collection type affects the contents of the collection. Use to specify the access type.
member.remarks: Using this attribute only makes sense if all collection methods are marked with this attribute.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType
member.summary: Provides a value for the to define how the collection method invocation affects the contents of the collection.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.None

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.ModifyExistingContent

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.UpdatedContent

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method is assertion method, i.e. it halts the control flow if one of the conditions is satisfied. To set the condition, mark one of the parameters with attribute.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the condition parameter of the assertion method. The method itself should be marked by attribute. The mandatory argument of the attribute is the assertion type.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType
member.summary: Specifies assertion type. If the assertion method argument satisfies the condition, then the execution continues. Otherwise, execution is assumed to be halted.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_TRUE
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to true.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_FALSE
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to false.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_NULL
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to null value.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_NOT_NULL
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to not null value.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.TerminatesProgramAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method unconditionally terminates control flow execution. For example, it could unconditionally throw exception.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.LinqTunnelAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that method is pure LINQ method, with postponed enumeration (like Enumerable.Select, .Where). This annotation allows inference of [InstantHandle] annotation for parameters of delegate type by analyzing LINQ method chains.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NoEnumerationAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that IEnumerable passed as a parameter is not enumerated. Use this annotation to suppress the 'Possible multiple enumeration of IEnumerable' inspection.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.RegexPatternAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked parameter is a regular expression pattern.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NoReorderAttribute
member.summary: Prevents the Member Reordering feature from tossing members of the marked class.
member.remarks: The attribute must be mentioned in your member reordering patterns.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.XamlItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the type that has ItemsSource property and should be treated as ItemsControl-derived type, to enable inner items DataContext type resolve.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.XamlItemBindingOfItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the property of some BindingBase-derived type, that is used to bind some item of ItemsControl-derived type. This annotation will enable the DataContext type resolve for XAML bindings for such properties.
member.remarks: Property should have the tree ancestor of the ItemsControl type or marked with the attribute.
